newsitem.title: ARGENTINA: Argentine top aide denies knew of alleged bribes.
newsitem.headline: Argentine top aide denies knew of alleged bribes.

text.p: President Carlos Menem's chief of staff Tuesday denied press reports that he knew about alleged bribes in a scandal involving a key Argentine state-owned bank and the U.S. computer giant IBM's local branch.
"I have all the necessary elements to prove I have nothing to do with it," Alberto Kohan told a radio interviewer.

Major dailies reported on their front pages Tuesday that former Economy Minister Domingo Cavallo told a judge that Kohan knew government officials paid bribes to secure the deal between state-run Banco Nacion and IBM to install computers.
According to the papers, Kohan told Menem and Cavallo at a meeting last year that his aide, deputy chief of staff Carlos Cattaneo, had paid bribes in the $250 million, 1993 deal.
"That meeting never took place," Kohan said.
Cavallo is abroad and his spokesman said he could not confirm or deny that the minister made the allegations in testimony to federal judge Adolfo Bagnasco Monday.
Kohan indicated he may sue Cavallo. "What he have here is alleged declarations. If those declarations are real, I will also go to court."
A federal court last month confirmed the indictment of 11 of the 30 former IBM Argentina and former Banco Nacin employees who Bagnasco had indicted in the case.

Banco Nacin last June canceled the deal and demanded that IBM refund $82 million in payments, but the company fired back, suing the bank in July for more than $86 million alleging "wrongful revocation" of the contract.

Then in August, Banco Nacin countersued the firm for $174 million. IBM denies any malicious intent, although it has admitted to errors. Other IBM Argentina deals are under separate court investigations.

Cavallo, fired in July by Menem, earlier this month launched a drive against alleged corruption in the government, accusing two ministers of manipulating judges and trying to cover up graft investigations.
